text: I’ve stuck with this error for 4  hours
you can provide a conflict resolution strategy
oh god my mac autocrrents damn quotes
What do I need to do so AS runs junit tests under src/test/ onthe JVM and not the device? :confused:
- manually select the test package and create the build config
it’s a pile of shit since they re-united the test suites

<@U04TK850N|langerhans> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/langerhans/F1UQ208DS/bildschirmfoto_2016-07-25_um_15.07.17.png|Bildschirmfoto 2016-07-25 um 15.07.17> and commented: So I can’t use that little icon?

initial_comment.comment: So I can’t use that little icon?

text: dunno, never tried running unit tests individually :confused:
okay, I can run a single test class by creating a junit config in AS, but that’s kinda annoying
meh, and there goes my motivation :smile:
<@U04TK850N>: right class the class or method and then run test
this will automatically create the config as well
interesting, that always brought up the device selection. Now after I manually created the config it works tho
I would guess that it thinks that it's an instrumentation test
Hm yeah, but I moved it from androidTest to test
maybe in your gradle build file the folder test is marked as instrumentation
How would I mark the folder as unit test in gradle?
you shouldn't need to mark it at all
I see I have `testInstrumentationRunner "android.test.InstrumentationTestRunner“`, could that be the issue?
I only have an exclude for androidTest
I also don’t have this selection under BuildVariants
So to get this right. You have a unit test such as `src/test/java/SomeUnitTest.java` and by right clicking and running it, it is giving you the device picker?
I would guess this is an AS bug then
haha and if I right click the „java“ folder, it works. Right clicking the class gives me the device picker
right clicking the package also works :neutral_face:
printing the sourceSets out shows that the test sources are at the right place
oh god damnit, I fixed it
I moved that class from androidTest to test and didn’t notice I already had a temporary andriodTest config for that class :confused:
So AS just re-used it instead of checking if it’s even still there
and here I was about to suggest that a config might have overidden the test environment selection :stuck_out_tongue:
AS tells me the line `public class StringUtils {` is not covered
would I cover that by calling the constructor?
the answer is yes and that is weird
for a class that only has static methods at least

<@U04TK850N>: yeah, I guess you have a private constructor right? For that case most people do not test the private constructor since they usually throw an exception there. I personally test it through reflection because that way I document in my tests that this class is never supposed to be instantiated.

This is what I have made to test a private constructor that throws an assertion error:

```
public static void assertThatPrivateConstructorThrowsAssertionError(Class<?> classToAssert) {
        Constructor<?> privateConstructor;
        try {
            privateConstructor = classToAssert.getDeclaredConstructor();
        } catch (NoSuchMethodException error) {
            fail("Should have had a private constructor", error);
            return;
        }

        privateConstructor.setAccessible(true);

        try {
            privateConstructor.newInstance();
            fail("Should have thrown AssertionError");
        } catch (InstantiationException error) {
            fail("Should have thrown AssertionError", error);
        } catch (IllegalAccessException error) {
            fail("Should have thrown AssertionError", error);
        } catch (InvocationTargetException error) {
            assertThat(error.getCause()).isInstanceOf(AssertionError.class);
        }
    }
```
That’s neat, I guess I’ll use that, thx!
I think I found it from a SO post and modified to kind of a custom assert
hm, what fail and assertThat methods are those?
btw the `assertThat` and `fail` are coming from the assertj api
I’ll include that probably, have seen that in some samples too
you want the latest 2.x (it's Android compatible)
People are on vacation and I’m done with the next release so I have a while to do something productive. So I’ll start getting into testing :smile:
Testing is awesome. I say start slow because the kind of issue with testing is that if you do it badly it can cause huge headaches
I suggest to read this book, it is amazing <http://artofunittesting.com/>
